title: What are some good research schools (PhD) for Artificial General Intelligence (not Machine Learning)? - Quora

response.answer_text: TL;DR - Sounds like you want a list of top schools for computer science - tied for first according to one list are: Carnegie Mellon, MIT, Stanford, and UC Berkeley. Longer answer: It seems that you’re making a few unfounded assumptions here about the relationship between weak and strong AI, and machine learning. Your first comment says: “Weak AI => Traditional AI. (not what I am looking for but better than Machine Learning which is not really core of AI)” Okay, I’ll buy the first equivalence that you’re making here, that “weak AI” is more or less the same as “traditional AI.” Both typically mean handcrafted algorithms designed to solve specific problems. The claim that machine learning “is not really core of AI” confuses me. What do you mean by the “core” of AI? The only things that I could think of that fit that definition are (1) math, and (2) algorithms, both of which taken together is more or less… computer science. Okay, so if you’re looking at schools for computer science, here’s one possible list of “best schools” for it: https://www.usnews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-science-schools/computer-science-rankings Of those, I wouldn’t really worry about specific rankings if a school is within plus/minus five or ten ranks of another, since they’re all pretty good places to start looking. I believe every school in the top twenty-five is a research institution. For a PhD, the lab group that you join is much more important than the school ranking, particularly when you get down to the level of wanting to do specific kinds of AI. Your second comment says: “Strong AI => Artificial General Intelligence (what I am asking about)”, but at the same time, you say you don’t mean machine learning. Given what we currently understand about machine learning, I think you’re misunderstanding either machine learning or AGI, or both. Nvidia has a good article talking about the relationship between AI, ML, and deep learning (The Difference Between AI, Machine Learning, and Deep Learning? | NVIDIA Blog). You’ll see that “artificial intelligence” is a catch-all term for a whole slew of techniques that meet the (fairly vague) criteria of making machine “more human-like.” In the weak AI case, we can make machines fairly human-like through algorithms with very specific use cases. If you describe to me how you do a simple repetitive task, I could probably design an algorithm that mimics that, making an “artificial intelligence” because it behaves in a way that a human would for that task. But for General Artificial Intelligence? That implies a program that can do any intellectual task a human could. The only way of approaching this with a “traditional” AI is to make a huge, messy pile of specific algorithms for every task that a human might encounter. Except learning. You can’t teach it to learn things, because that would be machine learning. But learning is exactly how humans learn to be “generally intelligent”! Babies are pretty dumb, as far as specific “intellectual tasks” go - but they can learn! See the contradiction with excluding machine learning from the task of building AGI? Most things that I’ve ever seen on frameworks for AGI first try to tackle the learning problem, usually in a way that mimics human learning in some way (be it through building neural nets, or learning from demonstration, or reinforcement learning, etc), because there’s no way that we know of where you can build up a “strong AI” from a domain-specific algorithms. Not that domain-specific algorithms are bad, mind you. This “weak AI” can be very good for many tasks because it leverages domain expert knowledge, and even the best uses of machine learning will often involve manually-provided domain knowledge at some level. I’d recommend looking a bit more into both machine learning and general algorithms before diving too deeply into finding a good PhD program for AGI.
